Lidz and Engle
Get PiDE Awards
For N-L Articles
Ex-News-Letter Editor-in-Chief
Richard Lidz has received a first
place award and Assistant Feature Editor Ron Engel a third
place certificate in a Pi Delta
Epsilon judging of outstanding
news and editorial writing for the
past college year.
Lidz's editorial was "The Russian Branch;" while Engel's story
was headlined "Reporter Records
Impression of 'Stand-In' at Northwood".
Waldo E. Edmunds, editor and
manager of the Alumni Magazine
of the University of California at
Los Angeles, was director of the
honorary journalistic fraternity's
contest.
Judges were: Robert E. G. Harris, editorial consultant of Frontier Magazine; John B. Jackson,
publications editor of Walt Disney
Productions; Joe Osherenko, publisher and editor of Fashion Publications, and Leonard Riblett, assistant city-editor of the Los
Angeles Examiner.

Cohen Announces
'59 Test Results
Results of the Honor 'Commission test, administered to all
freshmen during orientation, were
made public this week by Sanford
Cohen, Commission chairman.
Thre e-hundred and forty-six
freshmen took the test and Cohen
stated that steps will be taken to
enable the other 12 students to
take the examination in the near
future. Several students who failed to show a knowledge of the
workings or theory of the System
will be contacted by a committee
of the Commission concerning
their papers.
"The Commission was very well
pleased with the results of the
examination this year and will
endeavor during the coming year
to clarify some of the more nebulous concepts which were questioned by several members of the
class of 1959," Cohen said.
Results Enlightening
He added, "The results of the
test will enable future Commissions to better orient the freshmen, since it was evident that the
majority of this year's class lacked knowledge in particular aspects of the System."

test was that a witness to an apparant violation must obtain another 'witness before turning the

Freshmen elections will be held
next Wednesday and Thursday
ending the two-week campaigns of
41 candidates, Student Council
Bob Peinado announced this week.
On these two days, freshmen
will go to the polls to elect a president out of the ten candidates, a
vice-president out of seven men,
one of the two men running for
secretary, a treasurer from seven
candidates, and three reprtsentafives to the Student Council from
a field of 15 men.
Freshman Candidates
The freshman candidates for
president are Edward Weber,
George Bailey, Roger McKinley,
Richard Weinstein, Jed Jacobson,
Bennett Smith, Hector Van Lennep, Bruce Duffany, William Morrill, and Bob Sanford. Vice-presidential candidates are Don Alexander, Walter Johnson, Lee Snyder, Vic Ricci, Stephen Margolis,
Bruce Bendel, and David Danoff.
Candidates for treasurer are'
Pacy Oletsky, Alan Lakein, Tom
Park, Allan Goldman, Neil Zarin,
Guy Maseritz, and Mickey Levin,
while Joel Gordon and Ronald
tlitzer are competing for the post
of class secretary.
S C Representatives
Three. Student Council representatives will be picked from Erwin Sekulow, Howard Garrett, Joseph ,Jeziorski, James Tress: William Bartles, Donald Lowery, Dick
Auffarth, Thomas Toy, Dave Luce,
Louis Rosenburg, Howie Leibowitz, Sanford Schwartz, Richard
Binaulger, Bob Clarke, and Bob
Williams.

that the Young Republican club
is indeed "inactive" since he had
resigned as president, and, in conjunction with vice-president Futch, had declared the club to be
inactive.

New Dorm Chef Mandy
Commended By Jowett
"My new chef is chiefly responsible for the improvement in the
dormitory food," Mr. Jowett stated recently.
Emphasizing that he wanted the
dorm men to know the facts, Mr.
Jowett explained that the new
chef, Edward Mandy, had worked
with him for 18 years as chief
chef at Jowett's restaurant, the
Cavalier. Mandy's previous job
was chef at the Commander Hotel in Ocean City,

McCoy Professor
Dies During Class
Dr. Ivan E. McDougle, professor
of sociology at Goucher College
and instructor at McCoy College,
died Monday night as he was
calling the roll for his class.
Dr. McDougle, who died at 63
after teaching at Goucher for 31
years, frequently wrote articles for
newspapers on such subjects as
marriage, juvenile delinquency,
and the immigration problem.
He was a native of Huntingdon,
Tennessee.

Pershing Rifles Set
Future Activities

Under the leadership and direction of Pershing Rifles Company
Commander Cadet Captain Richard Taylor, changes are being
made in the Company policy to
provide for a more extended field
of activities .
Last year, the Hopkins Pershing
Rifles' unit was in one or two
parades and the annual regimental drill meet, held at regimental
headquarters on the Pennsylvania
State • University's campus, in
which nearly 500 men participated, representing 17 different
companies.
Plan More Activities
This year, the P.R.'s have already taken part in the Columbus
Day parade, on October 12, in
which they gave a distinguished
crack drill exhibition.
In the future, they plan to take
part in the Mummers parade in
Hagerstown, the Armistice Day
parade in Baltimore, the Apple
Blossom Festival in Winchester,
Va., the Cherry Blossom Festival
in Washington, • and finish up
with the regimental drill meet.

Dear Sirs:
My first reaction to the Bennett
article was one of casual concern
at an obviously one-sided view of
fraternity activity at the Hopkins. Certainly no one who has
been around the University for
the past several years will note
anything new in the objections of
Mr. Bennett. Many will find
snatches of genuine humor in the
descriptions of the four worst fraternities. My reason for writing,
however, is not to defend fraternities against these statements or
to deny his charges, for I do not
feel he has made an honest appraisal of. the situation. Rather,
I would like to question the NewsLetter as to the wisdom of their
Printing such a
stor y'
It seems to me that the NewsLetter, for want of a more stimulating article, , has resorted to
something bordering on sensationalism, in an effort to interest
its readers. That its readers were
Interested cannot be denied, but
I question whether or not such
headlines as "Liquor, Half-Nakedness Scored" should be the means
Whereby the student body is enticed to read the school paper.
This sort of thing is reminiscent
Of tabloid coverage, something
Which I always have thought to be
beneath the dignity of the NewsLetter of the Johns Hopkins University. If the purpose was to elicit
a host of guffaws from its readers, then I'm sure there are better means for getting us to laugh.

Of Perusal than an ungrammatical
tirade on Hopkins fraternities.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 28, 1955

Unbeaten Drexel To Oppose
Hopkins Gridders Tomorrow
With their entire squad fit and
ready to go, the Blue Jay gridders
will journey to Philadelphia tomorrow to meet Drexel Tech.
Drexel is expected by Hopkins
Coach John Bridgers to be a formidable obstruction to the Black
and Blue's quest for their initial
victory of the campaign. Last
year the Techmen routed Hopkins, 34-0.
"Drexel Best Team"
Tech, under the direction of
coach Edward B. Allen, is one of
the 39 remaining unbeaten college teams in the country, having
copped' four-straight decisions.
Working out of a straight-T formation, the Drexel attack has thus
far rolled up 88 points to 33 for
their opponents. Last week Tech
ground out a 33-14 victory over
Lycoming College of Williamsport,
Pa., and earlier they beat Hampden-Sydney, conquerors of Hopkins, 21-6.
ENDY CHINA, Hopkins Goalie, saves another score in the game
Last week the Jays matched
last Saturday against F&M, which ended in a 2-2 tie. LARRY WORTH,
touchHopkins fullback, and Parker, F&M center forward, are the other Randolph-Macon in the

Jay, Drexel Varsity Booters
To Meet Here To
Still looking for its second victory of the young 1955 fall season,
the Johns Hopkins Varsity soccer
squad faces Drexel Institute tomorrow afternoon on the latter's
field.
Last Saturday at Homewood the
Jay booters tied Franklin & Marshall, 2-2, after spotting the Diplomats two goals early in the game.
This tie put the Black and Blue
log even at one win, one loss, and
one tie.
According to Mickey Cochrane,
varsity coach, Drexel is "the best
team we'll meet this year." He
said that "the wing halfback and

inside positions of Drexel are very
strong." A year ago, the Dragon
squad topped the Blue Jays, 5-1,
at Homewood field and went on to
end its season with a 6-5-1 record.
Come From Behind
Last week at Homewood field,
the Hopkins team came from behind to tie up what originally was
a 2-0 deficit, and then battled
F&M on even terms throughout
two overtimes to a 2-2 tie.
Cochrane said that the Jays
played "a poor first half, but midway through the third quarter and
until the end of the game, they
played a much different brand of

Waverly's Newest

ball."
In the first quarter, the Diplomats jumped off to a 1-0 lead on
Bob Parker's goal and went ahead
2-0 in the third period on Inside
Left Bob Graeff's tally.
Collignon, Tebo Score
Dave Collignon got one past the
Franklin & Marshall goalie early
in the fourth quarter and a few
moments later Bob Tebo followed
suit to even up the score.

Jackets capitalized on three extra
points to send Hopkins down to
their four-straight defeat, 21-18.
Randolph-Macon received the
initial kickoff .and returned it to
their 18-yardline. On the second
play from scrimmage, the YellowJackets fumbled and Co-captain
Don Gallagher pounced on it,
giving Hopkins possession on the
18. After a line play gained four
yards, Fullback Jack Lawrence
broke through the middle and
romped to paydirt. Cliff Harding's
P.A.T. attempt, however, was
wide.
Jays Score Again
It was not long before the Jays
had the ball again as, on the first
play after the kickoff, RandolphMacon fumbled for a second time,
Gibson recovering for Hopkins on
the Yellow-Jacket 26. Four plays
later, Barrie Wood took the pigskin on a reverse and scampered
in the end-zone to make it 12-0.
Again the extra point attempt,
this time by Jack Lawrence, was
no good.
Early in the second period, a
fumble by John Steers was recovered by Randolph-Macon on
the Hopkins' 33. The Yellow-Jackets relentlessly ground out the
yardage and, after eight plays,
Halfback Bernie Pinchbeck
punched over from the one. John
Graham added the extra point
to make it 12-7.
Yellow-Jackets Lead
An intercepted pass and Charley
Nuttycombe's 16-yard end-run
gave the Yellow-Jackets another
score, and the extra-point by
Pinchbeck made the tally, 14-12,
at intermission. Phil Copage went
over from the one and another
extra point by Pinchbeck gave
Randolph-Macon a 21-12 lead late

in the third stanza.
Barrie Wood scored his second
touchdown in the final period as
he ripped off a 23-yard gallop off
a reverse. Lawrence's extra point
try was blocked. The rest of the
game was played on even terms,
Randolph-Macon having possession as the game ended.
Bridgers singled out Jack Lawrence for special praise, citing his
crushing running as the high spot
of the Hopkins attack. He also
lauded Ken McGraw for his line

Jays To Face Morgan State BIA Program Underway

After trouncing Gettysburg in
their first match of the season
last Saturday at Homewood, the
Hopkins rifle team will seek their

with Morgan State providing the
opposition.
Master Sergeant Charles Brown,
coach of the squad, feels that the
marksmen did remarkably well
against the Bullets, considering their limited amount of practice. However, he feels that
through the course of the season
the team score should improve
by at least fifteen points, as he
believes the team should compile one of the best records in
recent years.
Pacing the 1337-1301 victory
Over Gettysburg were seniors
Roger Van Riper and Bud Serivan, who shot 274 and 272, respectively. This pair is being
heavily counted on to lead the
nimrods throughout the season.
Bill Bicknell, Donald Griggs, and
Harvey Kasinoff, with scores of
265, 264, and 262, respectively,
rounded out the scoring for the
Blue Jays. Van Dyke and Musch
led the losers with scores of 271
and 270.
Sergeant Brown announced
that anyone who feels that he can
shoot 250 or better should come
out for the squad. The bulk of the
team is presently seniors, and
therefore lower classmen will be
welcome additions.

McCoy Professor
Dies During Class
Dr. Ivan E. McDougle, professor
of sociology at Goucher College
and instructor at McCoy College,
died Monday night as he was
calling the roll for his class.
Dr. McDougle, who died at 63
after teaching at Goucher for 31
years, frequently wrote articles for
newspapers on such subjects as
marriage, juvenile delinquency,
and the immigration problem.
He was a native of Huntingdon,
Tennessee.

Pershing Rifles Set
Future Activities

Under the leadership and direction of Pershing Rifles Company
Commander Cadet Captain Richard Taylor, changes are being
made in the Company policy to
provide for a more extended field
of activities .
Last year, the Hopkins Pershing
Rifles' unit was in one or two
parades and the annual regimental drill meet, held at regimental
headquarters on the Pennsylvania
State • University's campus, in
which nearly 500 men participated, representing 17 different
companies.
Plan More Activities
This year, the P.R.'s have already taken part in the Columbus
Day parade, on October 12, in
which they gave a distinguished
crack drill exhibition.
In the future, they plan to take
part in the Mummers parade in
Hagerstown, the Armistice Day
parade in Baltimore, the Apple
Blossom Festival in Winchester,
Va., the Cherry Blossom Festival
in Washington, • and finish up
with the regimental drill meet.

Dear Sirs:
My first reaction to the Bennett
article was one of casual concern
at an obviously one-sided view of
fraternity activity at the Hopkins. Certainly no one who has

the past several years will note

Mr. Bennett. Many will find

Interested cannot be denied, but

headlines as "Liquor, Half-Nakedness Scored" should be the means
Whereby the student body is enticed to read the school paper.
This sort of thing is reminiscent
Of tabloid coverage, something
Which I always have thought to be
beneath the dignity of the NewsLetter of the Johns Hopkins University. If the purpose was to elicit
a host of guffaws from its readers, then I'm sure there are better means for getting us to laugh.

s'ports editor was deprived

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 28, 1955

Unbeaten Drexel To Oppose
Hopkins Gridders Tomorrow
With their entire squad fit and
ready to go, the Blue Jay gridders
will journey to Philadelphia tomorrow to meet Drexel Tech.
Drexel is expected by Hopkins
Coach John Bridgers to be a formidable obstruction to the Black
and Blue's quest for their initial
victory of the campaign. Last
year the Techmen routed Hopkins, 34-0.
"Drexel Best Team"
Tech, under the direction of
coach Edward B. Allen, is one of
the 39 remaining unbeaten college teams in the country, having
copped' four-straight decisions.
Working out of a straight-T formation, the Drexel attack has thus
far rolled up 88 points to 33 for
their opponents. Last week Tech
ground out a 33-14 victory over
Lycoming College of Williamsport,
Pa., and earlier they beat Hampden-Sydney, conquerors of Hopkins, 21-6.
ENDY CHINA, Hopkins Goalie, saves another score in the game
Last week the Jays matched
last Saturday against F&M, which ended in a 2-2 tie. LARRY WORTH,
touchHopkins fullback, and Parker, F&M center forward, are the other Randolph-Macon in the

Jay, Drexel Varsity Booters
To Meet Here To
Still looking for its second victory of the young 1955 fall season,
the Johns Hopkins Varsity soccer
squad faces Drexel Institute tomorrow afternoon on the latter's
field.
Last Saturday at Homewood the
Jay booters tied Franklin & Marshall, 2-2, after spotting the Diplomats two goals early in the game.
This tie put the Black and Blue
log even at one win, one loss, and
one tie.
According to Mickey Cochrane,
varsity coach, Drexel is "the best
team we'll meet this year." He
said that "the wing halfback and

inside positions of Drexel are very
strong." A year ago, the Dragon
squad topped the Blue Jays, 5-1,
at Homewood field and went on to
end its season with a 6-5-1 record.
Come From Behind
Last week at Homewood field,
the Hopkins team came from behind to tie up what originally was
a 2-0 deficit, and then battled
F&M on even terms throughout
two overtimes to a 2-2 tie.
Cochrane said that the Jays
played "a poor first half, but midway through the third quarter and
until the end of the game, they
played a much different brand of

Waverly's Newest

ball."
In the first quarter, the Diplomats jumped off to a 1-0 lead on
Bob Parker's goal and went ahead
2-0 in the third period on Inside
Left Bob Graeff's tally.
Collignon, Tebo Score
Dave Collignon got one past the
Franklin & Marshall goalie early
in the fourth quarter and a few
moments later Bob Tebo followed
suit to even up the score.

Jackets capitalized on three extra
points to send Hopkins down to
their four-straight defeat, 21-18.
Randolph-Macon received the
initial kickoff .and returned it to
their 18-yardline. On the second
play from scrimmage, the YellowJackets fumbled and Co-captain
Don Gallagher pounced on it,
giving Hopkins possession on the
18. After a line play gained four
yards, Fullback Jack Lawrence
broke through the middle and
romped to paydirt. Cliff Harding's
P.A.T. attempt, however, was
wide.
Jays Score Again
It was not long before the Jays
had the ball again as, on the first
play after the kickoff, RandolphMacon fumbled for a second time,
Gibson recovering for Hopkins on
the Yellow-Jacket 26. Four plays
later, Barrie Wood took the pigskin on a reverse and scampered
in the end-zone to make it 12-0.
Again the extra point attempt,
this time by Jack Lawrence, was
no good.
Early in the second period, a
fumble by John Steers was recovered by Randolph-Macon on
the Hopkins' 33. The Yellow-Jackets relentlessly ground out the
yardage and, after eight plays,
Halfback Bernie Pinchbeck
punched over from the one. John
Graham added the extra point
to make it 12-7.
Yellow-Jackets Lead
An intercepted pass and Charley
Nuttycombe's 16-yard end-run
gave the Yellow-Jackets another
score, and the extra-point by
Pinchbeck made the tally, 14-12,
at intermission. Phil Copage went
over from the one and another
extra point by Pinchbeck gave
Randolph-Macon a 21-12 lead late

in the third stanza.
Barrie Wood scored his second
touchdown in the final period as
he ripped off a 23-yard gallop off
a reverse. Lawrence's extra point
try was blocked. The rest of the
game was played on even terms,
Randolph-Macon having possession as the game ended.
Bridgers singled out Jack Lawrence for special praise, citing his
crushing running as the high spot
of the Hopkins attack. He also
lauded Ken McGraw for his line
play both offensively and defensively. Linemen Don _Gallagher
and Sam Wright were also cited
for playing an outstanding game.

To Meet Teachers

Homewood Field.

Towson if they, hustle and play
However, the

coach also said, "The Towson
J. V.'s are really the second-string

boys who have had quite a bit of
experience in high school."

3-0 decision from Calvert Hall,
getting a fast start on a goal in
the first quarter by Saul DeSwann.
Two goals in the second and third
stanzas by Gil Schaumholz wrapped up the Jay scoring. After the
game, Coach Williamson stated,
"The boys looked good on offense,
but lacked spark in the last quarter."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 28, 1955

Undefeated Yearling Eleven
To Tangle With F And M
Fresh from their successful
Showing againts a heavier and
More experienced Baltimore Junior College eleven, the freshman
football team travels to Lancaster,
Pa., today to take on a strong
Franklin & Marshall freshman
team.
F & M handed the freshman
Blue Jays a 21-7 defeat last year
for Hopkins' only loss of the 1954
season. The Pennsylvania eleven
Put three touchdowns across in
the first period against a tense
JHU team.
"Although our boys then calmed
down and outplayed the opposition for the rest of the game,
holding them scoreless and scoring seven points, the first quarter
margin stood up. This year, however, we're ready for them, "states
Coach Bob Scott.

NEWS-LETTER

Jays Win 20-15
Last Friday, the yearlings opened their '55 season at Homewood
Field by defeating the visiting
Baltimore Junior College aggregation, 20-15.
Playing their first game together against a much larger opponent who had already played
four games this season, the Hopkins frosh got the jitters and had
trouble snapping the ball from
center to quarterback.
Meanwhile, the visitors scored
a safety on a play in which Hopkins Quarterback Bill Morrill was
driven back into the end zone,
and added a touchdown on a run
by halfback Sam Poulos.
The home team seemed to gain
their confidence in the second
quarter and snapped back with a
touchdown on a thirty-yard pass
play from Morrill to Dick Mahone,
who made a sensational catch
stealing the ball from the hands
of the BJC defender.
Offense Rolls
BJC retaliated in the waning
minutes of the ball game with a
twenty-five-yard pass from Hudson Fesche to Jack Kamps that
was good for a touchdown. Vernon Pearl kicked the extra point.

Meet Delaware
This Afternoon

will be looking for their first
victory over Delaware in five
years of competition.
Jay Coach Lincoln Simon said,
"I don't know much about the
Delaware team. I just know that
they are consistantly good. We are
looking for a tough race, but are
hopeful of a good showing.
In their first meet last Wednesday, the Jays defeated the City
College "B" team, 20-43. City College took the first place but Phil
Scheiner placed second to lead the
Jays. Hopkins won the meet by
bunching their men in the top
According to Simon, all the members of the nine-man squad are
pushing each other and everyone
is trying hard for the top spot.

Simon stated, "Delaware always
produces a fine cross country

PAGE EIGHT

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 28, 1955

Jays To Face Morgan State BIA Program Underway
— After Win Over Gettysburg With Football, Tennis
After trouncing Gettysburg in
their first match of the season
last Saturday at Homewood, the
Hopkins rifle team will seek their
second consecutive win at 2:00
p.m. today in the ROTC building
with Morgan State providing the
opposition.
Master Sergeant Charles Brown,
coach of the squad, feels that the
marksmen did remarkably well
against the Bullets, considering their limited amount of practice. However, he feels that
through the course of the season
the team score should improve
by at least fifteen points, as he
believes the team should compile one of the best records in
recent years.
Pacing the 1337-1301 victory
Over Gettysburg were seniors
Roger Van Riper and Bud Serivan, who shot 274 and 272, respectively. This pair is being
heavily counted on to lead the
nimrods throughout the season.
Bill Bicknell, Donald Griggs, and
Harvey Kasinoff, with scores of
265, 264, and 262, respectively,
rounded out the scoring for the
Blue Jays. Van Dyke and Musch
led the losers with scores of 271
and 270.
Sergeant Brown announced
that anyone who feels that he can
shoot 250 or better should come
out for the squad. The bulk of the
team is presently seniors, and
therefore lower classmen will be
welcome additions.
